We begin with the first class, and take the states in the order in |
which we have named them :
1. Kentucky, which has at present but the short road connection I
Louisville, Frankfort, and Lexington, proposes to extend this roatl
so as to intersect the Virginia road at Guyandotte on the one hani I
and on the other hand, to connect at the Ohio with the Indianapoljg I
and Madison Rail-road, whose ultimate destination is on Lake Midi I
gan. More lately a proposition is in discussion for the construction'I
of a road to the city of Nashville, and thence to Memphis, or moityl
directly to the latter point. A convention has been called to dotcr-
mine upon the practicability of this road. In behalf of the road it has
been ably urged—
" The rail-roads of New-York hold Cincinnati at present within their infln. I
ence ; and, operating from that point, New-York, by drawing trade in the oik I
posite direction, is sapping the prosperity of Louisville. An extension or ki
Memphis and Nashville road to Louisville will hold trade to its original direm
tion, and, by maintaining Louisville against the otherwise ruinous influence of
Cincinnati, preserve the prosperity of Louisville, as part and parcel of the prowl
perity of New-Orleans. All the trade on the north side of the road from Memphis to Nashville, will be caught on its rails and whirled off to New-Orleans. I
" On every consideration, it may be concluded that this Louisville and New- I
Orleans Rail-road—a road of 370 miles, in reality, though a road of 700 miles if 1
result,—is the first, as it is the best, in the policy of New-Orleans.
"Louisville, situated at a point where much of the business of the upper
country must, for a great part pf the year, take the rails, on its way to New-
Orleans, will necessarily become, under the influence of this road, the greatest I
city on the Ohio. The road to Memphis being the only means of preventing a
change in the direction of trade from Cincinnati, will compel that city to pay
tribute to Louisville ; whereas, without this road, business following the direej
tion of New-York, Louisville, absorbed into a system, in which, taking the pan
of an extremity which trade flows from, rather than a centre which trade flo**B
to, must inevitably dwindle into a tributary to Cincinnati. The importance on
this road to Louisville is, perhaps, even greater than to New-Orleans."* j
2. Tennessee having, in course of construction, or nearly complete^J

poses in addition the roads we have referred to as connecting Nasfr-i
